Award.AwardTitle: Interpolatory Model Reduction for the Control of Fluids
Award.AbstractNarration:
Fluid flow control problems are ubiquitous. They arise in important applications such as drag reduction (with the benefits of saving fuel or improving range/speed), enhancing mixing (for more efficient combustion), reducing structural fatigue, improved solidification and die casting, and efficient cooling in large indoor-air environments. However, the ever-increasing need for improved accuracy and complexity of the underlying flow problems lead to very large-scale dynamical systems whose simulations and control make overwhelming and unmanageable demands on computational resources. This research project aims to develop novel computational techniques and a new rigorous mathematical framework to solve large-scale flow control problems very efficiently. In addition, the project will develop a year-long graduate course on Model Reduction and Flow Control and will provide students with valuable interdisciplinary education.

The current state-of-the-art is to solve flow control problems by using reduced models constructed using the proper orthogonal decomposition. However, these models are limited in that they are only guaranteed to be accurate for a pre-selected range of inputs. This project will provide significantly improved tools for the efficient analysis and approximation of large-scale dynamical systems. It will also have direct application to model reduction for problems with bilinear and quadratic nonlinearities. Bilinear models arise in control problems for heat exchangers, and nonlinear partial differential equations with quadratic nonlinearities include the Korteweg-de Vries (shallow waves), the Kuramoto-Sivashinsky (turbulent flames), and the Landau-Lifshitz (magnetic fields in solid state physics) equations. Using rational interpolation, this research will lead to new algorithms to systematically perform high-fidelity, in most cases optimal, model reduction for linear and nonlinear systems associated with (discretized) flow equations. These reduced models will be used to design optimal feedback laws. The new framework will offer major advantages: First, unlike current approaches, the proposed control design will not require expensive full-order, time-accurate simulations for specific input trajectories or solutions of large dense matrix equations; the computational efforts lie in computing a steady-state solution and solving a modest number of sparse linear systems. Second, the reduced models will be uniformly accurate for a wide range of input profiles and will not depend on specific input trajectories. Third, the methodology will naturally create reduced models that respect the stability properties of the original flow.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Fluid flow control problems are ubiquitous and flow control has the ability to provide significant energy savings and performance improvements in a number of applications such as drag reduction (with the benefits of lower fuel requirements, improved range/speed, and reduced structural fatigue), enhanced mixing (for improved combustion and lower emissions), improved solidification and die casting, and efficient cooling with better comfort in large indoor-air environments. Since flow control problems lead to complex large-scale models, replacing these models by reduced-order models that are easy-to-simulate and control is of fundamental importance. Model reduction of the nonlinear dynamical systems appearing in flow control has been the main focus of this research proposal. The project not only focused on models that involve the Navier-Stokes equations, but also related models that exhibit bilinear and quadratic nonlinearities.  Bilinear models arise in control problems for heat exchangers and nonlinear PDEs with quadratic nonlinearities include the Korteweg-de Vries (shallow waves), the Kuramoto-Sivashinsky (turbulent flames), and the Landau-Lifshitz (magnetic fields in solid state physics) equations.

We have shown that interpolatory model reduction is an effective tool in flow control problems, eliminating the need for expensive full-order time-domain simulations. The cost of the control approach we developed is solving a steady-state problem followed by sparse linear solves. This approach reduced the cost of LQR problem drastically without affecting the overall performance of the resulting control.  Our testbed was to stabilize the steady-state solutions for the flow about side-by-side cylinders.  A consequence of the model reduction/control design approach was to characterize those flow parameters where rotational control is able to eliminate vortex shedding and return the flow to the steady-state solution.

We have also extended the optimal H2 model reduction framework to quadratic nonlinear systems. Since a wide variety of nonlinearities can be rewritten as quadratic, this result is expected to have a great impact for the community at large, providing an effective, iterative numerical algorithm for designing high-quality reduced models.

Furthermore, our research on time-limited model reduction is expected to provide critical tools for dealing with unstable dynamical systems such as those arising in linearized flows. Since these models can be simulated only for a small finite time interval, our optimality conditions in this setting will give the framework for an efficient reduced model.

We have also extended the data-driven Loewner framework for model reduction so that it can work with time-domain data. Since most flow problems, and flow simulations, produce time-domain simulations, this is important in extending these techniques to flow problems.

Discrete Empirical Interpolation Method (DEIM) is an effective tool in nonlinear model reduction. We have developed a stability analysis for DEIM in the case of noisy-data and showed that oversampling stabilizes. In most flow problems, the data is always noisy. Therefore, it is crucial to understand the effect of noise on DEIM. We have developed various numerical oversampling techniques to stabilize DEIM.

The development of efficient model reduction tools for large problems developed in this project will have an impact on a wide range of areas in science and engineering that rely on large-scale simulation and optimization, and inversion; ranging from the CFD community to the control community. Moreover, the developments on parametric bilinear models will have an impact in areas of science and engineering that deal with large-scale optimization. By making the control, optimization, and simulations cheaper, this research will contribute to the science and engineering community at large.

 The products of this research is expected to impact the flow control community at large; illustrating the importance of input-independent model reduction techniques (as opposed to using computationally expensive, input dependent approaches such as POD when a linear model is sufficient). The numerical effectiveness of the approach should make model reduction feasible even for more complex flow control problems.

 Two Ph.D. students have been supported under this project. Once completed, both Ph.D. dissertations will heavily consist of the research funded under this project. Ph.D. students gained theoretical and numerical expertise in model reduction of parametric nonlinear dynamical systems, unstable dynamical systems resulting from linearized flows, and DAEs; and theoretical and numerical expertise in optimization. Both students attended many scientific conferences and disseminated their results to the community at large. In addition to the talks by the Principal Investigators and the Ph.D. students at various conferences and seminars, the findings of this project were also incorporated into a graduate level class, which many science and engineering students attended.
